Trent's place was great! The suite is attached to the house where he lives, but with a private entrance off a shared porch. The host is nearby for any issues or questions, but the space is completely separate giving you privacy. We really enjoyed the peace and quiet, and the space was really cozy. There were chickens out back that we enjoyed watching strut around as we got ready in the mornings (they were not noisy). We saw Trent tending to the yard a few times, and he was always very friendly but gave us lots of space.
The bed was comfortable, the shower was warm, and the kitchenette was perfect. We took day trips to Luray Caverns and Harper's Ferry, and enjoyed the walking mall and museum (MSV) in Winchester. All were very easy to get to from the house.
This house is a real gem, and we would absolutely stay there again! We definitely recommend it!
Thanks Trent and Nameeta for giving us a comfortable, clean, and quiet place to stay, and for being wonderful hosts!

review_text:
I really enjoyed our 5 night stay here with my wife, infant daughter, and dog. It was a truly unique experience and we recommend it to people who want to check out all that Winchester has to offer.
Pros:
- Location. It's a short 7 minute walk to the Pedestrian Mall, which includes tons of restaurants, bars and breweries. Winchester is very walkable, and this is a great jump-off point.
- Design. The renovation was really well-done and it is really fun to stay in a converted gas station. The unit is spacious and you can tell Steve carefully thought out all of the details. One of the coolest places we've ever stayed.
Con:
- Noise. It's on a busy street and close to railroad tracks. There is also a unit above this one and we could hear them walking around a bit. Not too bad, but the noise is something guests should be aware of.
Our Winchester Favs:
- Museum of Shenandoah Valley
- Bonnie Blue
- Pizzoco Pizza (1 block away)
- Vibrissa Beer
- Big L's Bagels
- Walking the Pedestrian Mall

Crystal’s place is the perfect cozy cottage for a Winchester getaway. We wanted to take a few days to just relax before school/work starts getting busy again and to explore a new town. Crystal’s place was absolutely perfect for that. It’s on a quiet tree-lined side street with plenty of street parking across from an elementary school. It’s also a 4 minute drive or 15 minute walk from the adorable historic walkable part of Winchester that’s full of cute shops and restaurants. It’s very close to both major highways and scenic routes.
The house is a beautifully restored 1950s cottage with a lovely large wraparound porch with comfortable rocking chairs and a wide roof - it’s perfect for sitting and relaxing with a great book or enjoying a chat or just people watching. It was great in both sunshine and rain because the roof is wide enough to provide shade/rain protection. You enter into a lovely living room with some chairs and a comfy couch (which also folds out). The dining room and kitchen are well stocked with utensils/plates/cups/cookware as well as a Keurig and a tea kettle. There are spices/oil, etc. for cooking. Everything is spotless, and while the counters and sink are clearly new, the cabinets are really well restored originals which lends a nice touch to the house. There’s a super clean bathroom with soft fuzzy towels (and some mini soaps and shampoos in case you forget yours). The two bedrooms have comfortable soft beds with lots of pillows. And there’s a fantastic large backyard with a little patio that has a table/chairs and pretty fairy lights that come on at dusk! The AC works well in the entire house (we came in summer, so it was important!), and there’s a ceiling fan in the kitchen, too.
Crystal is super communicative and answers any questions you have very quickly, but doesn’t hover needlessly - excellent combo in an AirBnB host!
The town is lovely - highly recommend Bonnie Blue BBQ for brunch, Water Street Kitchen for dinner, and Red Fox Creamery for ice cream and milkshakes. The nearby Museum of the Shenandoah Valley is a delightful surprise - just a few minutes away, it boasts a historic home, lovely gardens, and the actual museum which has contemporary art, an exhibit on the history of the valley (from paleo-Indians to present day), and a marvelous room of beautiful miniature houses - think dollhouses but a million times more exquisite. The museum is also surrounded by a series of walking trails which are free and open to the public morning to dusk. Finally, if you’re in the mood for fresh produce, the Marker-Miller Orchard is a few miles away and has a fabulous market, pick your own fruit, a children’s playground, and a huge porch full of rocking chairs where you can sit and enjoy the view of the Blue Ridge mountains.
We had a fabulous stay and would highly recommend it to others!
